Trial_Design.evidence: people aged 60–69 years were randomized into the screening and control arms

Participants.evidence: people aged 60–69 years were randomized into the screening and control arms

Intervention.evidence: randomized into the screening and control arms

Objective.evidence: to determine the effects of faecal occult blood test (FOBT) screening of colorectal cancer (CRC) in outcomes beyond mortality

Method_Outcome.evidence: Differences in incidence, symptoms, tumour location, TNM categories, non‐vital outcomes and survival in the screening and control arms were analysed

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: people aged 60–69 years were randomized into the screening and control arms

Number_Analysed.evidence: 743 patients with screening‐detected tumours and 617 control patients with CRC were analysed

Result_Outcome.evidence: CRC was less common in women than in men (0·34 versus 0·50 per cent; risk ratio (RR) 0·82, 95 per cent c.i. 0·74 to 0·91)
